body:
Ran this in dev environment. Can confirm that it removes the weird logs I was seeing (take poison pill) from the logs.

+1

@saguziel sorry missed your comment somehow. I'm not completely sure I follow. Checking the return_code will ensure a task is still running if doing a kind of self terminate otherwise the normal "clean" process of termination will happen. 

It might be that there is a deeper issue with this code (you might be right), but that is not his change I think?
@saguziel I agree.
+1 LGTM, I have tested this and I no longer see the issue i had, Thanks !
@bolkedebruin Yeah, my bad for not mentioning, it's unrelated to your change but a deeper issue.

## [Current coverage](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2023?src=pr) is 66.81% (diff: 100%)


> No coverage report found for **master** at 6b2a3ca.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [6b2a3ca...15f1abe](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/6b2a3ca2ee4ee3415ef72ea1fa3fc694350e9efc...15f1abef288411539b512f6bdb572c4a54aa5447?src=pr)
@alexvanboxel

Running 1.8.0 beta 3 was not possible due to an alembic error when upgrading the database. This was even the case when running a complete new database.
This PR solved this issue and I now am running 1.8.0 beta 3 without issues.
Will merge as it prevents Travis from building correctly and user has reported it working.

> But as you suggest, adding a decode('utf-8') solves the issue on my side. #2008 

Will merge after successful build, to make beta compatible with Py3 again.

Looks good,it's isolated enough. And if I have problems with the Java operator I'll fix it, as well as adding support for the new 2.0 SDK. Templated dataflows for sure need to come after the 1.8.
@wrs can you please close this issue?

@alexvanboxel do you want this to go into 1.8.0? I'm not too happy with that (feature change at end of beta releases), but if you say it is isolated we could (and it avoids cherry picking for 1.8.0)

@criccomini Please be a bit more strict in the commit message - what and why not how.
@bolkedebruin it's all up to you. You're the release master.
@alexvanboxel what is your advice?
my advice is leave this out of 1.8.0
We'll leave it for a 1.8 patch then.
LGTM
Because the bash_operator has many uses, I am reluctant to add a step that materialize the entire log into the job memory instead of handing it off to the logging infrastructure.

@bolkedebruin Addressed comments and waiting for your LGTM. Would be nice to get this for the RC since there is a regression from 1.7.1 otherwise (and it makes things harder operationally since users will ask you why their dags aren't running).

agree with @artwr but it is very useful to capture the entire output sometimes. If @jhsenjaliya can add another option to capture only one last line or all, I think it would be best. To make it even more fance, add an option to pass regex expression to extract only needed piece from the output. Like in my recent case, I needed to extract counters from sqoop output which is very verbose as well.

I agree with you that it's not ideal. I spent about half a day debugging but it was slow-going (I even installed pyenv and used the same version of python in travis). Note that this test coverage was missing before so it's still an improvement. I tried binary searching the code with print statements but this was also slow going.

The travis error was that the import errors simply weren't added in all of the tests that should have added them for python 3.

When we have containers these kinds of reproducibility problems will go away.
K lets put it in then
@bolkedebruin, commit message revised, PTAL.
@bolkedebruin I merged the change and bumped the beta branch version to beta 5.
@fenglu-g revised the message myself, please have a look for future reference.
Marking this for 1.8.1
Marked for 1.8.1. if merge/comment conditions are met.

## [Current coverage](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2028?src=pr) is 66.97% (diff: 100%)


> No coverage report found for **master** at 6060f65.

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [6060f65...9c225a9](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/6060f653a1720a6255893ec7067d7e6eda1bffaf...9c225a93caefb60ad72624e6c108016fa106de76?src=pr)

@aoen what do you think ? 20sec run duration per test is something Im not really eager for.

In addition @fenglu-g you fixed the "no dag file present" earlier, so what is the real root cause now?
Ok I understand the issue now. Still not too happy with 20s.

We shouldn't rely on timeouts/sleeps these are a pretty bad antipattern for tests. I'm a little bit confused as to what the issue is. num_runs is set to 1 in these tests so how come the scheduler runs indefinitely?

@fenglu-g I think the code in https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2027 needs updating. num_runs should be respected also when there is no dag file present. I'm tempted to revert both PRs as the first introduced a larger issue than it solves: not many people will run airflow without any dags present.

(And then yes I have been to fast in merging, my apologies)

@bolkedebruin num_runs is keyed by dag file, what's the semantic of num_runs when there is no dag file? 

The case for empty dags is, IMHO, quite legit. Think about the case where one infra team sets up the airflow instances for  their dev teams.
@fenglu-g well what comes to mind is either a special "no_dag_file_present" key or a global (to the instance) key. Neither very clean I have to admit so open to suggestions.

I didn't dig deeply but I feel like the num-runs logic (loop num-runs times) should be moved to SchedulerJob._execute_helper:
```
        # For the execute duration, parse and schedule DAGs
        while (datetime.now() - execute_start_time).total_seconds() < \
                self.run_duration or self.run_duration < 0:
            self.logger.debug("Starting Loop...")
            loop_start_time = time.time()
```

something like:

```
for i from 1 to # of times to try to schedule each dag file:
  for dag in each dag file
     schedule dag
```


if no dags exist the inner loop would run 0 times.

I am not super familiar with scheduler job details. But I imagine dag files can be added to dag folder in the middle of the outmost for loop, if we don't track schedule runs on a per-file basis, some dag files may not be scheduled num_runs times.

@bolkedebruin @aoen I see the unit tests in #2018 are mainly used to check dag import errors. I hate absolute time in unit tests too. One way to fix the problem is to set up these tests in a way where there is one pre-existing valid dag file (so we don't go to the empty dag path). WDYT?
I am OK with this for now but I think the scheduler should behave in a sane way when no dags are found.

SG.

We spotted the no dag scheduler termination issue when we were setting up airflow for other teams.  The dags were not picked by the scheduler and we then realized airflow scheduler almost terminated instantaneously when started (num_runs was also set to -1 or unlimited).

Open to other scheduler behavior alternatives when no dag is found.

Any news on merging this?
Im holding off for 1.8.0, but it is fine for 1.8.1

@jhsenjaliya - Yes makes sense. Your suggestion works. Actually I am new to airflow and I saw the implementation of Presto Check Operator, so thought we could do the same for Vertica. That is also essentially doing the same just with a different conn_id.

Nice! I think this is something for @alexvanboxel or @criccomini to review.

Can you clean up your commit message please?

I'm sorry, can you please elaborate on what's incorrect about my commit message? I tried very hard to abide by the rules laid out in [http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/](http://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/)

@wwlian just remove all the info about the test's run in the commit message. This is information that you can supply with the PR message. The commit message is set in stone, with the PR message is for the reviewers.

I'll do a passover, but it's for 1.8.1 anyway so better to approve it after the release.
Gotcha, thanks for the clarification. Done :)
@alexvanboxel PTAL, thanks.

unit test result:

nosetests tests.contrib.operators.dataflow_operator:DataFlowPythonOperatorTest

Ran 2 tests in 0.019s
OK

@artwr this fixes an issue that prevents Airflow from running out of the box as the default config uses sqla+mysql for celery queue and results backend and the latest celery uses Kombu 4 that removed support for this. See Jira ticket.
PR against kombu https://github.com/celery/kombu/pull/687
Nice! Can you please correct your commit message (prepend with Jira Issue) and check lanscape issues?
Done. I've rebased the branch with master to get rid of the landscape issues.
I have this in an earlier PR. Please close this.

@bolkedebruin I have just rebased this branch in an attempt to get the landscape check to run correctly. This hasn't worked and now the Travis CI has an error, despite running successfully for out repo. I believe this is something transient and unrelated to this change. If possible would you be able to get the Travis CI to re-run the failed job and take another look over the changes?
I cannot trigger it. But you can through an empty commit.
Interesting, I wonder why I didn't see this when testing with pyenv 3.4. Thanks for fixing!
LGTM
LGTM
LGTM once tested

Thanks for this PR !
do you think this could have been implemented by bash_operator or ssh_operator ? since its basically running a bash command locally or remotely ? 
since I wonder how we will keep track of spark command changes.

Hi @jhsenjaliya 

You could of course implement this using a bash command. But in a production environment the spark-submit process will be light weight as the actual Spark driver is running on the YARN cluster inside of a container (when using `yarn-cluster`, which is most common). So it would not make sense to remotely execute the process on another machine.

The spark-submit command has been stable for a while. Many of the fine grained configuration options are submitted using the conf dict, if you like.

Does this answer your question, or am I missing something?

Cheers
LGTM but I think there's duplicate code for the GCS stuff--would prefer just using the gcs_hook.py stuff.
@criccomini could you elaborate a bit more? Are you suggesting moving the code that "parses" gs-uri to bucket/obj into gcs_hook?

Sure! The `google_cloud_to_local` method you wrote overlaps significantly with the `download` method in gcs_hook.py:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/contrib/hooks/gcs_hook.py#L47

I am suggesting deleting your method, and using the `download` method in the hook instead. You can instantiate a GCS hook in your operator, just like the dataflow hook.

LGTM

Will let this hang for a day for @alexvanboxel, and then merge if we haven't heard.

for remote execution one can also use ssh_operator.
I think once the spark-submit command is formed, its a matter of executing it either locally via bash or remotely via ssh operator. although building spark command based on parameters is useful functionality to get with this wrapper, it can execute with existing operator so that its easy to maintain afterwards due to reused code.
anyway, thats my 2 cents, I am not committer, so let see what others has to say in this. Thanks for explaining though.
